data.content: Until she looked more closely.
https://miro.medium.com/max/8000/1*PFQ81ILLSf28OPEpDqGY9Q.jpeg
Fiction Friday
Jacie stood up, rubbing her back. “I can’t do this any longer, Kenna. Don’t you have what you need yet?”
“Almost, not quite. Another half hour?” Kenna’s camera whirred.
“But you promised…” Jacie heaved in a long breath. “Never mind. Give me a minute?”
“One minute,” said Kenna, rolling out of her crouch. “We’ll lose the light.”
“I’ll lose my mind,” muttered Jacie, wrenching open another bottled water. She stared at her phone.
“Excuse me?” Kenna inspected the camera lens.
“Nothing,” said Jacie. “I need to…” Her fingers tapped, paused incredulous.
Kenna glowered, aimed the camera at Jacie again. “Thirty seconds.”
Jacie’s swift tapping ceased. She pressed SEND, pirouetted to the ground, and draped herself over tangled blankets.
“Despair! He’s left you again!”Kenna commanded, holding camera to her face and waving her free hand.
Jacie’s face sagged. A tear snaked down her cheek.
“Perfect!” Kenna’s voice swelled with admiration. “Love the tears!”
Head drooped and hair shielding face, Jacie snuck peeks at her phone. Genuine tears flooded fake ones.
Forty minutes later, Noah strode past lights, cords, and boxes.
“Babe!” He raised a hand to block the strobe lights, walking to Jacie. “I am so sorry!”
“Get out!” Kenna roared.
Noah clasped Jacie’s arms, helped her up from the wretched blankets. He wiped her face with his shirtsleeve, held her close, and murmured into her hair.
Seconds later, he roared at Kenna. “Jacie’s freezing! What is wrong with you?”
Motionless, Kenna kept her camera whirring. Her mouth creased into rare smile.
Noah pulled off his shirt and sheltered Jacie. She smiled and touched his cheek. Noah bowed his head and closed his eyes.
“We’re almost done and then you and me can find dinner,” said Jacie, stepping back and handing Noah his shirt. She looked at Kenna for agreement.
Kenna grinned at them. “We’re done. Got what I need.”
“Break-up to Make-Up,” Kenna explained to the judges. She waved at the series of photographs.
She sang the old song, nodding encouragement when the panel sang along.
The crabby old guy at the end of the table sang loudest, wiping unabashed tears at true love.
